result.execSummary:
The defendant Mitchell Ryan Engebretson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Battery by Prisoners [Modifiers: Repeater], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 940.20(1).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

superMiscConds.notes:
Defendant shall provide a DNA sample. 
Defendant shall not possess or consume any controlled substances unless prescribed and to be taken only as prescribed.
Defendant shall submit to random, observed testing for controlled substances.
Defendant shall have such assessments, treatment, counseling and programming as DOC deems appropriate.
Defendant shall pay restitution, if any is requested for his or the victim's medical bills.

Defendant shall be employed full time or seek work at a rate of 3 job applications per week and document monthly with DOC.
Defendant shall document any interview efforts with DOC. 
Defendant shall obtain a GED, HSED, or other high school equivalency diploma

records.addlTxt: Defendant Mitchell Ryan Engebretson in court, in custody from WSPF.  Attorney Peter A. Bartelt in court for Mitchell Ryan Engebretson.  Attorney Anthony Joseph Pozorski Sr. in court for State of Wisconsin. Per agreement, defendant will plead to charge. State recommends 3 years WSPS (1in and 2out) consecutive to previously imposed sentences with the following conditions for extended supervision: pay any restitution for his or the victim's medical expenses, to work full time or seek 3 job applications a week, document any interview efforts with DOC, pay costs, counseling that DOC deems appropriate, and submit to random drug testing. Court reviews plea questionnaire and finds defendant freely and knowingly waives rights. Defendant pleads guilty to charge. Court accepts plea and finds defendant guilty. Court reviews rights lost due to felony conviction. State heard. Attorney Bartelt heard. Defendant heard. Court heard and orders 3 years WSPS ( 1 year in and 2 years out) consecutive to previously imposed sentences. Conditions of extended supervision are to pay restitution if requested for defendant and/or victims medical bills, to have such assessment, treatment, counseling, or programming that DOC deems appropriate, not to possess or consume any controlled substances unless prescribed and to be taken only as prescribed, submit to random, observed testing for controlled substances, to obtain a GED, HSED, or other high school diploma equivalency, to be employed full time or seek 3 job applications a week and provide documentation to DOC monthly, document any interview efforts with DOC, and to provide a DNA sample. Court waives court costs. Defendant is not eligible for programming.
Plea/sentencing hearing on September 22, 2022 at 11:30 am.

Defendant Mitchell Ryan Engebretson appeared by video, in custody at Grant County Jail.  Attorney Anthony Joseph Pozorski Sr. in court for State of Wisconsin. Court explains charges, penalties, and right to counsel. Defendant referred to SPD. State heard and no bonded needed. Defendant sentenced to prison in other cases. Court heard and orders no bond. Defendant is to contact SPD today. Once SPD has appointed preliminary hearing will be set. Court finds good cause to waive time limits for preliminary hearing.
